messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Becky, I would agree with Barry that your fuchi-kashira look like late Higo work. The Higo school is a nice school, and did good work. Their style spread and
messages.messageBody:
Becky,

I would agree with Barry that your fuchi-kashira look
like late Higo work. The Higo school is a nice school,
and did good work. Their style spread and was often
copied. I too think the design is of a very stylized
dragon. It might be what is known as Edo Higo (Higo
style manufactured in Edo). The sharp shape of the
kashira is uncommon.

On the sword, I cannot say much. It is unsigned. It
doesn't seem any of us recognize that mark. I was
hoping someone would.
Without a signature and with the sword blade "out
of polish" it will be hard for us to say what school
or person made the blade. Many very old blades (of
high art value) are not signed, but also many 1920s to
1945 blades (of low art value) were unsigned. Someone
with experience in assessing out of polish
"closet-finds" like yours should take a serious look
at it. You sword may be a diamond,- or it may be a
dud. Given that it has some fair fittings of older
origin (not the military issue of WW2), I would say it
has a fair chance at being a decent blade. That is no
guarantee, -just my gut feeling.

Curran

>
> Becky

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Becky et al - This appears to my eye to be the katakana SU , not likely you can see it unless your computer has Japanese turned on but it looks like this; ス
messages.messageBody:
Becky et al -
This appears to my eye to be the katakana "SU", not likely you can
see it unless your computer has Japanese turned on but it looks like
this;

ス

I would look for this mark on the seppa (spacers) or other fittings,
I could be way off but suspect this is an assembly mark. Like putting
"As, Bs and Cs" on car parts then putting all the parts marked B
together to make one car. I think you have a Showa-to there, but
we'll need more photos to be sure.
-t



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Ahhhhh - I hate to bring an adverse view, but I didn t even go to the books because that  V  mark is the most un-Japanese mark I have ever seen on a nakago
messages.messageBody:
Ahhhhh - I hate to bring an adverse view, but I didn't even go to the books because that " V " mark is the most un-Japanese mark I have ever seen on a nakago (45 years...). Honestly, it is very hard without the sword in hand, but that mark in the orientation shown looks like hachi or a katakana tsu (my katakana is rusty so forgive an error, but I see three strokes). The conclusion here is that it is a Meiji or Taisho period sword, as the patina on the nakago looks "dignified" and of some age so it can't be a Showa period gunto. All guess work, but that " V " mark is very strange indeed...

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: excelsiorilluminati

Sent: Wednesday, January 03, 2007 5:55 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?


Hi All, Meanwhile I have tried to match that marking on the nakago.
It is no kanji that I can ID, nor is it a sosho derivative or kana in
the books. Anyone? Becky, when you've the time maybe pics of the
hamon and closeups of the nakago, machi area and kissaki will help.
Nice puzzle, just need all the pieces. John
.

messages.msgSnippet: Milt - thanks - no, it isn t that one.  The pattern I ve seen on my friend s FG looks really like Arabic/Persian script.  I ll see if I can get a picture of
messages.messageBody:
Milt - thanks - no, it isn't that one. The pattern I've seen on my friend's FG looks really like Arabic/Persian script. I'll see if I can get a picture of it. He has taken it to Japan and no one there he saw has seen anything like it. Always something interesting in Nihonto.

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Becky, Thanks, No, the fuchigashira aren t what I thought they might be.  They are stylised clouds with possibly a highly abstract cloud dragon around the
messages.messageBody:
Becky, Thanks,

No, the fuchigashira aren't what I thought they might be. They are stylised clouds with possibly a highly abstract cloud dragon around the centre of the fuchi. It isn't clear enough to see. I think these are quite nice and have a Higo look to them???

Regards,
Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: BECKY WALLACE
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, January 03, 2007 11:58 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?


I have posted the requested pictures. Hope they help. I also did as a friend of mine at work suggested and performed a rubbing on the tang. The character that looked like a Y now looks like a Y with a "n" attached to the bottom right side. I tried to draw it in Power Point - I think I captured the gist of it, but the arms of the Y aren't crooked like my left side is. I think I've seen this character before. Later if I have time, I'll try and scan the rubbing so you can see what I actually see, but for now I have to run.

Becky

Curran Campbell <neobliviscar@...> wrote:
Becky,

Happy New Year!
I'd agree with John, Barry, and Rich. My interest is
in fittings, so I agree with Barry in that the fuchi
(and probably the kashira too) looks interesting. We'd
love to see more photographs, if possible. Just be
gentle with the tsuka (handle), but don't be afraid of
it.

The nakago (tang) of the sword isn't signed, but does
hold some promise at first glance. If you can take a
whole shot of the nakago, it would be most beneficial
to the sword guys on the list.
Is Harry Watson on this list? Any chance you will
be in Dallas this year at the gunshow she mentioned?

Curran
.

messages.messageBody:
I have posted the requested pictures. Hope they help. I also did as a friend of mine at work suggested and performed a rubbing on the tang. The character that looked like a Y now looks like a Y with a "n" attached to the bottom right side. I tried to draw it in Power Point - I think I captured the gist of it, but the arms of the Y aren't crooked like my left side is. I think I've seen this character before. Later if I have time, I'll try and scan the rubbing so you can see what I actually see, but for now I have to run.

Becky

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Becky, Happy New Year! I d agree with John, Barry, and Rich. My interest is in fittings, so I agree with Barry in that the fuchi (and probably the kashira too)
messages.messageBody:
Becky,

Happy New Year!
I'd agree with John, Barry, and Rich. My interest is
in fittings, so I agree with Barry in that the fuchi
(and probably the kashira too) looks interesting. We'd
love to see more photographs, if possible. Just be
gentle with the tsuka (handle), but don't be afraid of
it.

The nakago (tang) of the sword isn't signed, but does
hold some promise at first glance. If you can take a
whole shot of the nakago, it would be most beneficial
to the sword guys on the list.
Is Harry Watson on this list? Any chance you will
be in Dallas this year at the gunshow she mentioned?

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Becky and All, Woud it be possible to get good shots of the fuchi and kashira, please???  I fancy I can see a particular pattern in them that I would like
messages.messageBody:
Dear Becky and All,

Woud it be possible to get good shots of the fuchi and kashira, please??? I fancy I can see a particular pattern in them that I would like to see more clearly. A friend has a fuchigashira that has gold inlay that looks like Persian writing. It may simply be an imaginative, random pattern, but your pieces sort of look similar...

Regards,

Barry Thomas
(Australia)

----- Original Message -----
From: BECKY WALLACE
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, January 02, 2007 1:11 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?

OK, with your encouragement, I have disassembled my sword, taken pictures and posted them in my folder "Becky's Sword". They are the last 5 pictures in the folder. If the sword blade is signed it appears to be with a single character that looks something like a Y. It isn't very clear and the pictures aren't very good, but if anyone can tell anything, I'd sure like to know it.

Thanks,

Becky

bungotakadasword <MuramasaIII@...> wrote:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, BECKY WALLACE <SNDE92BW@...> wrote:
>
> Wow, I can't believe it. The scan you put in my folder. The one
top left is identical to mine. Same crickets. And the signature is
identical to the one someone posted as a mino. So now I know about the
tsuba. So what about the sword? Is the maker of the sword and the
tsuba generally completely different people? schools? are they
totally disassociated or might there be some swordsmiths that tended to
use tsubas from this particular school?
>
> Becky
.

messages.subject: Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Becky, I got really excited when I went to your photos and at first glance saw what appeared to be the ichi kanji. Goodness an ichimonji , no way. Then
messages.messageBody:
Hi Becky, I got really excited when I went to your photos and at
first glance saw what appeared to be the 'ichi' kanji. Goodness
an 'ichimonji', no way. Then the little stroke that makes it look
like 'a y' as I read in your letter afterwards grounded me. I can't
ID that mark. Interesting. John

messages.msgSnippet: OK, with your encouragement, I have disassembled my sword, taken pictures and posted them in my folder Becky s Sword .  They are the last 5 pictures in the
messages.messageBody:
OK, with your encouragement, I have disassembled my sword, taken pictures and posted them in my folder "Becky's Sword". They are the last 5 pictures in the folder. If the sword blade is signed it appears to be with a single character that looks something like a Y. It isn't very clear and the pictures aren't very good, but if anyone can tell anything, I'd sure like to know it.

Thanks,

Becky

top left is identical to mine. Same crickets. And the signature is
identical to the one someone posted as a mino. So now I know about the
tsuba. So what about the sword? Is the maker of the sword and the
tsuba generally completely different people? schools? are they
totally disassociated or might there be some swordsmiths that tended to
use tsubas from this particular school?
>
> Becky

based on your pic # 4........... all you have to do is remove that wood
peg ( behind the fuchi ) and the whole " handle " will come off and you
can take pics.

I labelled it " mino " because I put it with a Mino sword.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: Wow, I can t  believe it.  The scan you put in my folder.  The one top left is identical to mine.  Same crickets. And the signature is identical to the one
messages.messageBody:
Wow, I can't believe it. The scan you put in my folder. The one top left is identical to mine. Same crickets. And the signature is identical to the one someone posted as a mino. So now I know about the tsuba. So what about the sword? Is the maker of the sword and the tsuba generally completely different people? schools? are they totally disassociated or might there be some swordsmiths that tended to use tsubas from this particular school?

Becky

Curran Campbell <neobliviscar@...> wrote:
Becky,

I posted a scan in your folder. It should answer most
of your question. According to Gary Murtha's Sword
Fittings book pg 44, it is probably a tsuba by Kyoto
Kiyonori or one of his students.

I've seen this tsuba a few times over the years. If
you (carefully) remove the pin holding on the tsuka
and look at the face of the tsuba that was under the
tsuka, you will (maybe 50/50 %) see a gold 'KAO' mark
like that on the tsuba images uploaded to your folder.
The Kao will probably allow us to attribute it to a
specific person, althought the KAO shown by Murtha and
that recorded by Haynes are somewhat different for
these guys. Still, we should have a good idea.

According to Murtha, Kiyonori was "A Kyoto artist.
Signed with gold inlaid kao. His favorite design being
crickets in grass. One of his students was Atsuiye who
changed his name to Noriiye."

They are nice tsubas. One of the fellow listmembers
had one a few years back. If he sold it, he could
probably tell you the value best.
I did not look closely, but do the fuchi-kashira
match the tsuba in design? That would be nice.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Fwd: Can anyone ID this tsuba?
messages.msgSnippet: I m taking this sword to the Arms show in Dallas next weekend to have it disassembled by someone that knows what they are doing - I d probably destroy any
messages.messageBody:
I'm taking this sword to the Arms show in Dallas next weekend to have it disassembled by someone that knows what they are doing - I'd probably destroy any value it might have - the handle seems fragile. I have yet to see if the blade is signed, but figure it is and need to know the swordsmith before I know if it is junk or not. While apart I will photo the tsuba and post pictures. The tsuba is loose right now to the extent that I can see that it is signed, but of coures the symbol is undecipherable to me - it is a single charater and I can't photo it due to the angle right now. All I know right now about this sword is that my one of my Husband's relatives, who was a marine in WWII, got it on Okinawa during the war. It is obviously not a WWII era sword and hence the mystery and intrigue.

Becky

Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote:
agreed, no Heianjo, but no books here, I know there are a few of these
in Peabody's, well I think there are. I have seen them also before.

Cheers and Happy New Year

Rich Turner

Becky
